title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm must secure free trade deal
story: As the Prime Minister heads into the most signicant EU summit, she must secure the Brexit promised to the ­British public.Now is the time to deliver for the United Kingdom on the Conservatives’  General Election manesto promise to take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade.It does not get clearer than the pledge: “We will no longer be members of the single market or customs union.”  Our manesto also promised that our laws would be made in the UK and interpreted by judges here, not in Europe. That’s why the Prime Minister’s Chequers proposal was not right.Under such a deal, we would be required to follow EU laws under the EU rule book and we would still be subject to the European Court of Justice.We would be out of Europe, yet still run by Europe. Any proposal that is brought forward and put to Parliament needs to take back control of our laws and make sure the European Court has no say over us.  So what should Theresa May do  The answer, once again, is set out clearly in the  Conservative manesto.It says: “We will seek a deep and special partnership including a comprehensive free-trade and customs agreement.”  That’s why the Prime Minister should move on from her Chequers proposal and seek an advanced free-trade deal with the EU. A comprehensive free-trade deal, like the EU’s free-trade deals with Canada and Japan, is what our manesto promises require.Such a deal would ensure we take back control of our laws, borders, money and trade. It would honour the referendum mandate. It would be in line with our manesto commitments. And it would work for the EU too. The Government’s objection to this is the supposed dficulty of keeping an open border in Northern Ireland.For this reason, Government figures claim we cannot seek a trade deal with the EU unless this problem is solved. This is nonsense.Clear proposals have been set out by two former Northern Ireland Secretaries as to how a frictionless border can be maintained under a free-trade agreement. These proposals have been endorsed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis and Good Friday Agreement architect Lord Trimble.Moreover, former Cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith has set out how we can build on the system of joint border controls at Dover to avoid delays or friction at the UK’s borders — including in Ireland. This would work for the EU’s rules and ensure a positive future relationship going forward.This approach is not simply a bad use of taxpayers’ money. It breaks another manesto pledge.For our  manesto says “it is necessary to agree the terms of our future partnership alongside our withdrawal, reaching agreement on both within two years” of our serving notice to leave the EU. In other words, by the end of March next year.So it is wrong for the Government to agree withdrawal terms without sorting out the full detail of our future relationship. A temporary fix does not honour the referendum mandate, it does not keep our manesto promise and it certainly fails to look after our hard-earned money.Moreover, would this temporary fix really be temporary  Just ask the people of Norway how such a deal turned out for them. In  they signed the European Economic Area Agreement. They were told by the EU their sovereignty would be respected. Yet  years later, this “temporary” arrangement has become permanent.Meanwhile, the cost has increased ten-fold and nearly , EU directives and regulations have been implemented through Norway’s EEA agreement.Our Government should fear to tread such a dangerous path. Voters will not tolerate any “temporary” arrangement becoming permanent. They would see it as a betrayal. People voted to leave the EU because they wanted change. They believed in Britain and the land of opportunity we can build. They voted to take back control of our laws, money, borders and trade.The Conservative manesto promised that we would leave the EU altogether. That we would seek a free-trade deal and a new national future.Now is the time for the Government to honour the referendum mandate and the Conservative manesto by seeking a free­-trade deal with the EU that enables Britain to become an economic powerhouse in the decades to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: starving dog skinny bones north shields car park
story: The neglected Staffordshire Bull Terrier, named Ayma by vets caring for her, was discovered in the early hours of Friday morning by a member of the public walking in North Shields, Tyne and Wear.The RSPCA are now looking into the incident in which the poor Staffy was so seriously underweight that all of her bones were visible through her skin.RSPCA inspector Cathy Maddison, who is now investigating the appalling case, says no amount of experience working in animal rescue can prepare you for seeing a dog so horrendously starved.She said on Friday: I dont know how she is still alive and what is even more heartbreaking is just how lovely and friendly she is, despite what she has been through.She is now on fluids at the vets and has been given some much-needed food.Sadly, it is really touch and go for her as she is so emaciated so it’s not knownshe will pull through the night.Unfortunately, Cathys fears were confirmed when vets took the dficult decision to put Ayma to sleep last night after her appalling condition deteriorated.The Staffy wasnt microchipped but was believed to be about four years old and was found covered in fleas.The man that found Ayma told Cathy he was on his way to a job interview when he came across the poor pup.He wrapped her up in a towel to keep her warm and contacted the RSPCA to get urgent help, but ultimately her sickness was too far gone for vets to save her.Earlier this year, The Sun and the RSPCA put out a call for people to come forward and adopt puppies and dogs that have been abandoned or abused across the UK.Tens of thousands of dogs are abandoned in Britain every year for a iety of reasons ranging from poverty, human sickness, and the puppy trade churning out designer dogs.

title: universal credit sanctions under 30s iain duncan smith
story: New figures show that more than  per cent of penalties under the Governments controversial new system land on Brits under .Campaigners have demanded that the system - which has been beset with problems so far - be halted while the issues are fixed, or even scrapped altogether.Today the architect of the scheme, Iain Duncan Smith, said ministers would be betraying the Just About Managing Britsit didnt help plough extra money into the scheme.He told Skys Sophy Ridge on Sunday programme: Theresa May stood on the steps of Downing Street and said I want to look after those who are just about managing.Universal Credit is the single best system to get to those who are just about managing... we need to put the money in. title: pregnant woman lost baby says unborn child saved her life
story: Louise Abbott, , was  weeks pregnant when Leroy Margolis, , veered across the road and ploughed into her car.The nursery worker, from Braintree, Essex, was saved from suffering fatal injuries due to the baby bump taking the impact.But tragically baby Layla died from a fractured skull and heartbroken Louise had to give birth to her because she was too injured for a cesarean.Louise has now received an undisclosed financial settlement to pay for the specialist therapies and support she is continuing to receive following her ordeal.She said: The crash, finding out Layla had died and then giving birth to her is something that will stay with me for the rest of my le.It is almost impossible to put into words the effect it has had on me and [husband] Laurence.We go through a full mix of emotions each day knowing that Layla should still be part of our family and thinking what , even though the events were clearly out of our control.Louise was being driven to a wedding party on October , , in Cambridgeshire when Margolis overtook a lorry at mph.He lost control at a staggered junction and smashed into the car Louise was travelling in with a witness describing his driving as suicidal.The former Lloyds banker was caged for two years last year after being convicted of causing serious injury by dangerous driving.Louise was later told by medics she may never have children because of one of her oies had been rendered useless as a result of her injuries.But her and husband Laurence, , welcomed a healthy daughter named Avery last year.At first we felt guilty because of Layla but Avery was not a replacement for Layla.Layla will also be part of our family. Avery will know all about her big sister but we will always be sad that they never got to meet each other and grow up with one another, forming the bonds and friendships sisters should.Louise said previously: Our babyhad little nails and hair and she was fully formed, fully developed, ready to be born the next day.But now, we know that without I might not be alive had it not been for the accident- and little Avery wouldnt have been born, and I wouldnt be here to have more children in the future.Because of the extra blood I had in me due to my pregnancy, and because Layla cushioned the bump, I wouldnt have lived had it not been for her.I will never forget those words, Im sorry, your baby has died.The mum has joined their legal team at Irwin Mitchell in using Baby Loss Awareness Week to speak out about the support available to other families who have experienced the heartbreak of losing a child.Tracey Storey, Partner and specialist serious injury lawyer at the firm, said: It may have been two years since Layla’s death but the pain and loss that Louise and Laurence continue to experience is still understandably extremely raw.While no amount of money will ever make up for what has happened, we are pleased that Louise has been able to access the support she needs so she, Laurence and their family can try and look to the future the best they can while never forgetting Layla.

story: Five Pound World aims to take Britain by storm over the next  months with ambition to take the retail spaces left vacant by Poundworld.Poundworld collapsed in June with the loss of , jobs and  stores.Five Pound World opened its first branch in Burton-on-Trent, Staffs, last month and two more are due to open this month  in Derby and Walthamstow in North London.The discount chain is the brainchild of Dev Singh, managing director of Opium Group, a firm describing itself as trading in ious sectors all over the world.Everything costs £ with plans to also sell cheaper products in multi-buy deals at the same price point. title: historic drakes island off devon coast goes on sale for 6m and could be transformed into caribbean style hotel
story: But you’ll need a cool £million to take on this six-acre property off the coast at Plymouth, once used to defend against France and Spain.Unfortunately it’s not as yet a Caribbean-style paradise, thanks to its centuries-old derelict gun battery, former barracks, crumbling ablution blocks, commanding officer’s house and guardhouse.However the current owners of Drake’s Island hope a buyer will be drawn to the site’s huge potential as a luxury hotel and spa complex – for which there is planning permission.Former Plymouth Argyle owner Dan McCauley bought the island from the Crown in  for £,.His son, Aidan, , told The Sunday Times his dad described it as “the jewel in the crown of Plymouth”.“We want to see the place come back to le. It has to come back to le,” he added.In August this year Plymouth Live reported that the development of a “stunning waterfront location entertaining the rich and famous” could finally begin after a marine licence was granted to enable the repair of the ageing jetty.It said this work would clear the way for “experts to gain access and begin transforming the maritime jewel into a world-class spa complete with a high-end hotel, conference facilities and a posh restaurant with commanding views of Plymouth Sound.”Formerly known as St Nicholas Island, after a chapel there, it was used during the Tudor period, having been fortied from “at least the th century”, according to Plymouth City Council.The first fortication was commissioned as part of the country’s maritime line of defence during the war with France, and strengthened in the late s by the installation of guns and garrisons during the war with Spain.It was named after Sir Francis Drake as he set sail from the island in  to famously circumnavigate the globe.Interestingly, two centuries later, Royal Museums Greenwich says, “the first recorded submarine fatality occurred north of Drake’s Island just two years after Captain Cook’s departure [from Plymouth in ], when a carpenter named John Day died while testing a wooden ing chamber.”Although regarded as a heritage site of national importance, with signicant wildle, the council last year gave the green light for a major resort complex.This includes conversion of the existing Grade II buildings and the Scheduled Ancient Monument casemated battery.Drake’s Island’s website explains its plans include reusing the former Governor’s island house, barrack block and ablutions building “as the core for the hotel development”.The barracks will be turned into a -room hotel, while the casemates will become luxury suites.An extensive network of underground tunnel, originally intended for the store of ammunitions and safe passage to the Casemates, will provide access and points of interest for visitors to the island.They will also “serve as cellars and wine stores for the hotel,” the website said.John Kinsey, a director at JLL in Exeter, which is marketing the property, said: Drakes Island is a remarkable piece of British history and a much-loved landmark that the Plymouth community holds close to its heart.

title: cops let thief go 9k tools
story: Cops were called when neighbours spotted shty men breaking into Slawek Zarebas vehicle overnight on Saturday.Officers arrived and found a man loading nearly  boxes of gear from Mr Zarebas van into another car in Morden, South London.But instead of nicking the thief on the spot, blundering cops had a chat with him and allowed the chancer to drive off with a car full of loot.Tradesman Mr Zareba , woke the next morning to find his whole van emptied.He now has no tools to work with and has slammed cops for letting the theft unfold in front of them. He said: Its absolutely ridiculous what happened.I cant understand what the police are playing at.It was am at the time and I was inside my house, completely unaware of what was happening.Instead of quizzing the thief, checking the car registration details or even knocking my door to double-check, they had a talk with him and watched as they let him waltz off into the night.The police havent even apologised or been back to get fingerprints from my van or look at the CCTV.I havent been able to work since and am losing money.CCTV footage shows the moment police arrive and speak to the thief - who has his own car boot open and a collection of Mr Zarebas tools hanging out the back.Cops bizarrely then get back in their patrol car and drive off behind his car - only for the man tosome  minutes later and continue raiding the van.The gaffe follows reports that cops are not properly investigating nearly a million reported crimes a year.Home Office data shows police abandoned nearly three quarters of car theft probes without identying a suspect.And figures show four fths of house burglaries and nearly half of shoplting cases go unsolved.A Met Police spokesman said: Police were called to reports of a vehicle being broken into in Morden, South London.Officers attended and found a man loading tools from a van into another vehicle.The man gave an explanation for his actions and no arrests were made.Police later established the tools had been stolen. An investigation was launched and a warrant was executed at a property in Morden.A number of items were recovered.The suspect remains outstanding and enquiries continue. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: posties to combat loneliness with check and chat visits to thousands of vulnerable and isolated elderly brits
story: The PM will today reveal postal workers will take time out of their usual delivery round to speak to lonely and isolated people as she launches a cross-Government Loneliness Strategy.GPs will also be asked to prescribe social activities such as community art clubs or cooking classes for the lonely.And Ministers will launch a review of the impact the explosion of social media is having on loneliness among Britain’s youth.Some , older people have not had a conversation with a friend or relative for over a month. And GPs claim loneliness can be linked to conditions such as heart disease or Alzheimer’s.The PM will say: “Loneliness is a reality for too many people in our society today. IT can affect anyone of any age and background.“This strategy is only the beginning of delivering a long and far reaching social change in our country.”Postal workers launched a pioneering ‘Call and Check’ service in Jersey on the Channel Islands four years ago – with staff chatting to OAPs, help arrange grocery deliveries or book doctor’s appointments for them.The Royal Mail has approved trials of a similar scheme in Liverpool, Whitby and New Malden in Surrey.Theresa May committed £ million for charities and community projects tackling the misery of loneliness in June.It followed a ground-breaking report from the Jo Cox Commission established by the Labour MP murdered during the Referendum campaign.Announcing the strategy today, the PM will say three quarters of GPs claim to see between one and five people a day suffering with loneliness.A survey earlier this month claimed  to  year-olds were the “most likely” to feel lonely because of the pressure to present a perfect le on social media.Sports Minister Tracey Crouch was given the brief of ‘Minister for Loneliness’ in January.Speaking yesterday she said businesses from Sainsbury’s to the National Grid and British Red Cross had also signed up to do more to help their staff cope with feeling lonely.She said: “Nobody should feel alone or be left with no one to turn to. title: brexit chancellor air passenger duty
story: They claim a £.billion cut to the “levy on holidays” will get Britain ready for take-off after Brexit.And Ulster unionists in the DUP will take their demand to the doors of the Treasury  in another high profile attack on Theresa May’s Government – which they prop up in the Commons.Dozens of Tories are believed to support the call.APD has soared from just £ in  to £ on one-way economy ticket for long-haul journeys.Campaigners claim this can make up nearly a third of the ticket price for some flights to Dubai.Short haul routes cost an extra £ in APD in economy.Writing for The Sun, ex-Tory Cabinet Minister Priti Patel and the DUP’s Sammy Wilson said: “The summer holidays are a distant memory and families across the country will be starting to save up for next year’s trip.“Yet a big chunk of that cost doesn’t pay for your holiday - it goes straight into the government’s coffers.“The UK has the highest short and long haul aviation tax anywhere in Europe. Cutting air passenger duty is exactly the kind of policy that Brexit Britain should embrace.”Cutting it will make holidays cheaper for families who have been hit by pricier trips because of the weaker Pound.On long haul flights, there is a £ tax on an economy ticket. This is a huge leap from  when it was just £.There is no environmental justication, it is simply used to fill the Treasury’s coffers. Slashing it will also boost businesses hoping to sell products outside of the EU. It will show Brexit Britain is an outward-looking, global nation.We hope you’re listening, Mr Hammond.“It would make saving for hard-earned holidays easier, and it would also make the UK a more attractive place to come to.The Chancellor this March launched a review into APD in Northern Ireland as promised in the confidence and supply deal Theresa May struck with the DUP after last year’s Election disaster.Belfast Airport claims that nearly a million passengers have switched to Dublin in the past year, where the tax was axed in  by Ireland’s then transport minister, current Taoiseach Leo Varadkar.Ms Patel and Mr Wilson said a cut would prove Northern Ireland was “open for business” as well as other regional UK airports.The total contribution from APD for the Treasury has ballooned from £ million in  to £. billion – a rise of  per cent.But campaigners claim there is little evidence the money is being used to tackle environmental issues.Frontier Economics last month claimed more than  new airline routes may be added at UK airportsthe Government abolished APD altogether.The think tank claimed an extra  routes would become viable, including eight new destinations from Aberdeen, nine from Belfast and seven from Southampton.James Roberts, political director of the Taxpayers Alliance, said: “Air Passenger Duty manages to fly under most people’s radar, but it has to be one of the most pointless taxes out there.“There’s no real environmental justication – it’s just a straight up levy on both family holidays and air trade links.”The summer holidays are a distant memory and families across the country will be starting to save up for next year’s trip. Yet a big chunk of that cost doesn’t pay for your holiday - it goes straight into the government’s coffers.Buying a ticket for a long-haul flight out of the UK will set you back at least £ in air passenger duty, a tax levied on all adult flyers from UK airports. So for a family of four flying in economy class, you’d have to fork out £, on top of whatever the airline is charging as their fare and airport charges.This is quite the increase from when two rates of either £ or £ was introduced in .Research released last year by A Fair Tax On Flying, which campaigns for a reduction in air passenger duty, shows that this tax makes up  per cent of the average cost of a European short-haul ticket.Looking around, you quickly realise our tax on flying is giving Brits a raw deal. The UK has the highest short and long-haul aviation tax anywhere in Europe. Countries nearby, like Ireland, have abolished their air taxes after seeing the bad effects it had for their economies. Northern Ireland gets hit particularly bad, as holidaymakers head to Dublin to dodge the unnecessary costs.Flying does have consequences, like emissions and noise for people who live right near airports, but the £. billion it raises pays for those many times over.Cutting air passenger duty is exactly the kind of policy that Brexit Britain should embrace. It would make saving for those hard-earned holidays easier, and it would also make the UK a more attractive place to come to. It would be a massive boon for Northern Ireland. Tourists and exporters would see that the country is open for business.Committing to cut air passenger duty in half would be a great message and save flyers millions. That’s why MPs from dferent parties are supporting this campaign from the TaxPayers’ Alliance and A Fair Tax On Flying. The Chancellor should commit to this in next week’s budget and make saving for holidays that bit easier.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. story: NewsBrexit pizza club plots Theresa Mays downfall ahead of EU summit as last-minute talks end in deadlockBrexiteer Cabinet ministers could launch a bid to kill off the PMs Brexit plan after Dominic Raab made a failed last-minute dash to BrusselsShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe PM is facing the sack from No as Ministers plot over pasta how to kill Brexit plans "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is facing the biggest threat to her premiership with a two-pronged attack from warring Tories over her Brexit plan. Brexiteer Cabinet ministers will tonight plot over pizza how to kill it off, which could lead to her being toppled. In a second equally lethal threat,  letters demanding a vote of no confidence had by Sunday evening been submitted by Tory MPs. That is just four short of the number required to trigger a leadership contest. It comes as Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab ed empty-handed from urgent talks in Brussels last night - despite reports UK and EU negotiators had a technical deal. Today its reported all further technical talks have been called off until Wednesday - when Theresa May must thrash out a political deal at a frantic EU summit. Government sources admitted this morning they had run into a signicant problem over the issue of the Northern Ireland border.  That could throw the entire Brexit timetable into doubt and ramps up the chance of a damaging No Deal exit. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said last nights talks were a bid to seeprogress could be made on outstanding issues and a sign of “how much effort we are putting in”. But EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier tweeted: “Despite intense efforts, some key issues are still open. A joint statement by the Brexit Department and  Downing Street did not even commit to the issue being resolved on Wednesday - it only said there would be progress. The statement said: In the last few days UK and EU negotiators have made real progress in a number of key areas. However there remain a number of unresolved issues relating to the backstop.  “The UK is still committed to making progress at the October European Council.” The backstop – a mechanism to avoid a hard border – poses a threat to Mrs May’s leadership. The EU’s version would keep just Northern Ireland aligned with Brussels’ rules. Mrs May’s counter-proposal is for a “temporary customs arrangement” for the whole of the UK. But Tory Brexiteers fear it could become an open-ended position which would prevent free trade deals around the world. Mr Hunt insisted only Mrs May could get the right deal for Britain, adding: “She is battling for Britain”. But Tory MP Nadine Dorries suggesting installing Mr Davis as interim leader, adding: “Getting May out and him becoming an interim leader may be the only way to deliver Brexit and FTA.” And former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said Britain was at a moment of crisis, adding: The EU is treating this country with naked contempt.  The “pizza club” has reportedly met secretly during times of crisis in Brexit negotiations. Its latest meeting comes ahead of a crunch summit of EU leaders on Wednesday. And at least nine Ministers want Mrs May to drop her current EU plan when the Cabinet meets on Tuesday. Former Brexit Secretary David Davis on Sunday urged a full-scale rebellion against her. He wrote: “It is time for the Cabinet to exert their collective authority. This week the authority of our constitution is on the line.” Allies of Mr Davis said he has been contacted by several Tory MPs urging him to run for the leadership. He is understood to be prepared to runthere is a contest.  Critics of Mrs May believe the no confidence vote threshold could be passed by Wednesdayshe refuses to change her position. At least four Cabinet Minister are rumoured to be seriously considering quitting over her Brexit plan. Speculation has centred on Andrea Leadsom , Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey . But Scottish Secretary David Mundell, and Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, could also quit. In a letter to the PM, the pair said the integrity of the UK “remains the single most important issue for us”. They indicated they will not tolerate a situation in which Northern Ireland is treated dferently from the rest of Britain over the EU customs issues. A source close to Ms Davidson said the issue was a “red line” for her, while a source close to Mr Mundell said resigning was a “logical outcome” for those who do not agree with Government policy. title: gps prescribe dancing cookery classes
story: NewsGPs to prescribe dancing and cookery classes to patients suffering from lonelinessTheresa May said social prescriptions would reduce demand on the NHS and improve patients’ quality of leShareCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLonely people will be encouraged to take part in cookery classes, walking clubs and art groups"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGPs are to prescribe social activities for patients suffering from loneliness, the Government will announce today. Instead of offering pills, family doctors will be encouraged to use “social prescribing” to refer lonely people to activities including cookery classes, walking clubs and art groups. Announcing an extra pound.million for community projects, such as creating new community cafes, art spaces or gardens, Theresa May said social prescriptions would reduce demand on the NHS and improve patients’ quality of le. Launching the first loneliness strategy, the Prime Minister confirmed English GPs will be able to refer lonely people to community and voluntary activities by , as she paid tribute to murdered Labour MP Jo Cox, who had campaigned to end loneliness before her death.  Mrs May said: “Jo Cox was absolutely right to highlight the critical importance of this growing social injustice which sits alongside childhood obesity and mental well-being as one of the greatest public health challenges of our time. “I was pleased to be able to support the Loneliness Commission set up in Jo’s name and I am determined to do everything possible to take forward its recommendations. “This strategy is only the beginning of delivering a long and far reaching social change in our country - but it is a vital first step in a national mission to end loneliness in our letimes.”  Loneliness is one of the greatest public health challenges of our time, Mrs May said, and is linked to illnesses including heart disease, strokes and Alzheimer’s disease. About , older people have not had a conversation with a friend or relative in more than a month and three-quarters of GPs said they see up to five people every day suffering loneliness.  Speaking on behalf of the Jo Cox Foundation, Jo’s sister Kim Leadbeater said she was delighted to see the strategy being launched. She said: “The work on loneliness has been a hugely important part of Jo’s legacy and it is heartwarming to see how much progress has been made on the subject since her murder.” As well as social prescriptions, postal workers will be encouraged to check in with lonely people on their delivery rounds in a new scheme with Royal Mail in Liverpool, New Malden and Whitby.

The national interest is largely forgotten with Brexit a battleground for Tory rivals, bloodlust opponents agonising over what’s best for them rather than the country. When the post of Prime Minister’s the goal of wavering Ministers calculating whether it’s better to back or sack May, the jobs of millions who voted to Leave and Remain are collateral damage for Tories obsessed with their own futures. I’ve never witnessed a Government disintegrate with the poisonous animosity of May’s collapsing regime. The reigns of Thatcher, Major, Blair, Brown and particularly Cameron finished in acrimony – an iron law of politics the tenure of all PMs end in failure. Yet this Conservative uncivil war’s unmatched in bile, squabbling Tories too busy scoring points against each other to champion Britain in negotiations with  united European neighbours.  At such a crucial juncture for the country, revolting Conservative MPs coming close to submitting the  letters triggering a self-indulgent leadership contest is proof Brexit is all about them, not you. Plastic patriots, right-wing nationalists blindly waving flags to hide their cluelessness, call the shots in a misgoverning party’s increasing Ukipisation that is symbolised by the membership of a purple Colonel Blimp former MEP, offensive reactionary Godfrey Bloom. So Andrea Leadsom, Penny Mordaunt and Esther McVey fret over staying or going, boosting or ruining their chances of the Premiership. Jeremy Hunt and Sajid Javid fuss over supporting or opposing May’s Brexit plan for the same reasons.  And David Davis and Boris Johnson compete to be the most aggressive quitter. Whatever Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, another with his eye on the personal prize, agrees with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier is irrelevantMay loses the Tory Party, never mind Parliament. She is left relying on Labour rebels in a salvage operation, just as Ted Heath depended on John Smith to take us into Europe in . The best deal remains Britain’s continued EU membership. The tragedy is too many MPs are scared to tell the truth.

title: theresa may brexit statement deal
story: NewsTheresa May makes urgent Brexit statement as UK admits talks have hit signicant problemThe Prime Minister will address the House of Commons after UK sources admitted a "signicant problem" and No Deal was branded "inevitable"ShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsUK government sources admit theyve hit a major road block "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May will today make an urgent Brexit statement after the UK admitted talks with the EU have hit deadlock. The Prime Minister will address the House of Commons from .pm in a bombshell moment with just two days to go to a crucial summit. This morning her key allies, the DUP, declared a no-deal Brexit is probably inevitable as government sources admitted they were stuck in a signicant problem. A dash to Brussels by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab ended in failure last night - and further talks are said to be off until a summit of  leaders on Wednesday. Last night Downing Street pointedly refused to say Mrs May - who faces a two-pronged Tory pizza plot against her leadership - was hoping for a deal at this weeks meeting. They only said she is expecting progress. SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon said today it appears unlikely a deal will be reached. If so, she said, the need to change course becomes all the more necessary as no responsible government should contemplate No Deal. The Scottish First Minister said it would be better to stay in the EU single market, extend the date of Brexit or even back a second EU referendum than be railroaded into a reckless blindfold Brexit.  Preparations for quitting without a deal on  March  are now poised to spring into action within weeks. Top civil servants have warned contingency plans must start being put into effect by the end of the month - whatever the situation, the Times reports. Otherwise they face not being ready with stockpiles of medicine and extra customs and border checks in time for  March . Talks between the EU and UK are still in deadlock over the issue of the Northern Ireland border. The EU wants to put in checks between the province and the rest of the UK. And No was looking at dropping an end date on its backup plan to keep borders open. Both plans enrage Tory Brexiteers and the DUP .  Theresa Mays spokesman declared today that the EU “continues to insist on the possibility of a customs border down the Irish Sea. The spokesman added: [That] is something which Parliament has already unanimously rejected and which is not acceptable to the Prime Minister”. Today its reported all further technical talks have been called off until Wednesday - when Theresa May must thrash out a political deal at a frantic EU summit. That could throw the entire Brexit timetable into doubt and ramps up the chance of a damaging No Deal exit.  Wednesdays summit in Brussels was meant to be the moment of truth that would open up a final crossing the Ts gathering in November. Evena deal is reached, it then has to pass a vote in the UK Parliament - where Tory Brexiteers and the DUP have vowed to defeat any sign of compromise. Theresa May relies on her  DUP allies to prop her up because she has no majority. Today DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson told the Belfast News Letter: Given the way in which the EU has behaved and the corner theyve put Theresa May into, theres no deal which I can see at present which will command a majority in the House of Commons. So it is probably inevitable that we will end up with a no deal scenario. Mrs May is expected to meet Sinn Fein leader Mary-Lou McDonald and its leader in the Northern Ireland Assembly Michelle ONeill in Downing Street later.  Labours Sir Keir Starmer said the Government must now publish details of its revised plans for the Irish border. At the moment we dont even know what the proposal is that everybody has fallen out about over the weekend, the shadow Brexit secretary told BBC Radio s Today programme. That needs to be looked at and scrutinised in Parliament. Irelands ambassador to the UK, Adrian ONeill, said events in Brussels were a setback and could increase the prospect of a no-deal Brexit. He told BBC Radio s Westminster Hour: Time is running out, there is no doubt about that. In all member states, preparation for all eventualities are ramping up quite signicantly.  Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt admitted talks were going through a dficult period but that there was always going to be a moment like this. Arriving in Brussels for a meeting of the EU Foreign Affairs Council he said a deal was still possiblethere was goodwill on all sides saying: There are one or two very dficult outstanding issues but I think we can get there. Whether we do this week or not, who knows  But Brexiteer Cabinet ministers will tonight plot over pizza how to kill off Theresa Mays plan - while reports suggest she has  no confidence letters against her, four short of triggering a leadership battle. Tory MP Nadine Dorries suggesting installing David Davis - who has called for a Cabinet insurrection - as interim leader. And former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson demanded Mrs May chuck her plans, adding: The EU is treating this country with naked contempt.

title: what brexit deal chequers uk
story: NewsWhat is the Brexit deal  Where we are with Chequers and why UK and EU are utterly stuckThe UKs odds of a deal are slipping away just days before Theresa May meets  EU leaders. Heres what the hells going on with the Northern Ireland border and why no one can agreeShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe EUs Michel Barnier, PM Theresa May and the DUPs Arlene Foster are in deadlock"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe could be days from knowing the future of Brexit Britain.Theresa Mays four-dimensional chess was meant to turn to checkmate at a summit with  EU leaders on Wednesday  October.But the UK admits talks are stuck after a frantic dash to Brussels by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab proved fruitless. EU officials have warned time is running out - and with every day the chance of a No Deal Brexit grows greater.So what is stopping a deal from happening  Who wants what, and why are they so opposed to each other  Heres a guide that you dont need a political PhD to understand.  What is the problem  Everyone disagrees over how to solve a double-locked puzzle - the Northern Ireland border.Lock number one: At the moment, goods and people can move freely with no fences, guards or checks between Northern Irelandand the Republic of Ireland .This must not change, because it will break up the peace process that was hard-won in . Lock number two: At the moment, goods and people can move freely with no fences, guards or checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.This must not change, because it will break up the union of the United Kingdom.  So Theresa May somehow has to rip the UK away from EU rules - yet not have any checks on either of these borders. How can you have dferent rules in dferent territories with no checks between any of them them  What the EU wants  The EU dreamed up a backstop - backup plan - that would prevent those locks breaking until there is a proper trade deal. Under the EUs plan, Northern Ireland would use many of the same customs rules as the EU to prevent a hard border - checks - with the Republic. But this would then force us to check goods travelling between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, such as live animals and animal products. EU negotiator Michel Barnier said this could be as simple as scanning bar codes on the side of lorries in ferry ports. But Theresa May warned this would draw a border down the Irish Sea and break up the Union.And thats enraged an until now little-known party called the DUP...What the DUP want  The Democratic Unionist Party , a Northern Irish political party, are utterly opposed to anything that draws a line between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. That definitely includes customs checks. The DUP are very influential, because last year Theresa May handed over pound.bn to Northern Ireland in exchange for their  MPs voting with her government. DUP officials are now saying No Deal Brexit looks inevitable after their leader, Arlene Foster, visited Brussels and couldnt find a breakthrough. But the DUP fear theyll be left behind in a compromise they cant back. If that happens, they have threatened to vote down the Budget on October .AndTHAT happens, it will pile enormous pressure on a little someone called Theresa May...What Theresa May wants  Theresa May has drawn up a dferent backstop to try and please both the EU, and the DUP. Under her plan, the WHOLE of the UK would stay in EU customs rules for a temporary period while a full trade deal is worked out. This would prevent border checks on all sides. But no one can agree how long it will last. She wanted to make this plan end no later than  December . But the EU said this was impossible, because how can something be a backup planit has an expiry date  So officials are now looking at continuing EU customs rules in the UK temporarily in name - but actually, without a set end date. The problem is this will stop the UK signing trade deals around the world until the backstop lts. It will keep the UK locked into the EUs orbit for an unknown period.And as you might expect, that has infuriated Tory MPs...What Tory MPs want   or more Tory MPs are in three groups. A small crop of hard Remainers a big bunch wholl be loyal to Theresa May and up to  Hard Brexiteers. Its this last group, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg and Boris Johnson, who make the noise, stir up headlines and fuel talk of toppling Mrs May with a leadership bid. These Tories are sick of the fudge and compromise. They want Hard Brexit, a sharp break from Brussels, and a Canada Plus deal which would be like the EUs agreement with Canada , but, erm, better. Critics accuse these Tories of skating over crucial practical details, sweeping away protections against chlorinated chicken and dumping workers rights.Critics who include the Labour Party...What Labour want  Labour arent in office but they have one big power - deciding whether to vote for the Brexit deal in Parliament. The party has set six tests that the final Brexit deal must passbefore Labour will vote in favour. The most controversial is number two - because pretty much everyone knows we cant have a Brexit with the exact same benefits as we do now. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer insisted he was just using the same language as Tory ministers. But even his shadow cabinet colleague Barry Gardiner has branded the tests bollocks. And not all Labour MPs will agree with what the party decides. Some, like Caroline Flint, have suggested they will back Theresa Mays plan because the alternative is leaving with no deal at all.Does it ensure a strong and collaborative future relationship with the EU  Does it deliver the “exact same benefits” as we currently have as members of the Single Market and Customs Union  Does it ensure the fair management of migration in the interests of the economy and communities  Does it defend rights and protections and prevent a race to the bottom  Does it protect national security and our capacity to tackle cross-border crime Does it deliver for all regions and nations of the UK  What is Chequers and how does it fit in   The UKs current Brexit plan is based on a deal Theresa May drew up at Chequers, her country retreat, in July .At the time it was seen as a major sht to soft Brexit - prompting hard-Leaver Cabinet ministers David Davis and Boris Johnson to resign.The Facilitated Customs Arrangement would keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. Under this plan, the UK would share a common rulebook with Brussels for goods, including agricultural and food products. Britain would also collect some, but not all, customs tarfs on the EUs behalf. It was a bid to solve the Irish border in the long term. But it was rejected by Labour, Tory MPs, some Cabinet ministers, and the EU, who said it will not work. That is why UK officials have been drawing up new plans to solve the Irish border question behind closed doors... and why weve had to write a new explainer. Where do we go from here   - October :  EU leaders meet Theresa May in Brussels for a moment of truth summit. It looks like a full deal wont be struck. But crucially, they will decide whether theres enough progress to call another summit in November. End of October : No Deal preparations have to begin in the UK government no matter what, because otherwise they wont be ready on time.  October : The Budget. It will spell out no deal preparations and be a test of loyalty for the DUP, who are supposed to vote with the government but could rebel. Mid-November : The UK is hoping for a final Brexit summit where she it seal not just a deal, but a political declaration on future trade. This is danger moment one, where Theresa Mays Cabinet ministers could resign or trigger a leadership coup. End of November : MPs hold a vote on any deal in Parliament. This is danger moment two for Theresa May, who will be in deep, deep troubleshe loses the vote. She claims the UK will leave with No Deal anywayshe loses. But Labour say she should be forced back to the negotiating table call a general election or even trigger a second EU referendum.  March : Brexit Day. If theres a deal, this will be a total anticlimax because a transition will be in place. If theres No Deal, planes could be grounded, ports jammed up and customs checks thrown into chaos at pm.  December : If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - will end.

story: NewsDiner told his £ shoes werent posh enough to eat at Towie stars restaurantMichael Farrell, , was hoping to have a romantic birthday meal for his we Keelie at Elliott Wrights Olivias restaurantShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMichael Farrell says he was told is shoes werent posh enough for Olivias "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British tourist was left fuming after being told his pound shoes werent posh enough for a Towies star swanky restaurant. title: harry meghans baby wont prince
story: NewsMeghan Markle pregnant: Why new royal baby wont be a prince or princess or get a HRH royal titleThe boy or girl, expected in the Spring of , will not have a royal title due to limits imposed by Prince Harrys great great grandfatherShareCommentsByLaura Elston:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are about to embark on their first Royal Tour - and Meghan is pregnant"Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Sussexs baby, expected in Spring , will not be a prince nor a princess unless the Queen steps in. King George V - Harrys great great grandfather - limited titles within the royal family in . This means Harry and Meghans first born, as a great-grandchild of the Queen, is too far down the line of succession to be an HRH. The baby will be seventh in the line, pushing Princess Eugenie - wed on Friday - to th. George V declared that: The grandchildren of the sons of any such Sovereign in the direct male lineshall have and enjoy in all occasions the style and title enjoyed by the children of Dukes of these Our Realms.  The eldest son and heir apparent of a duke can use one of his fathers lesser grade peerage titles by courtesy, according to Debretts. So a first son of Harrys would become Earl of Dumbarton - one of the subsidiary titles Harry received from the Queen on the morning of his wedding. A daughter would be LadyMountbatten-Windsor, and any subsequent sons LordMounbatten-Windsor. But the Queen could make changes to allow Harry and Meghans children to be HRHs and princes and princesses.  Ahead of Prince Georges birth, the monarch issued a Letters Patent to ensure the Cambridge children had fitting titles. Without this Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis would have been a Lady and a Lord instead, but Prince George, as the eldest son of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales, would still have been a prince. The Queen could decide to do the same for Harry and Meghans baby. But this royal infant is unlikely ever to accede to the throne. The duke may heed the words of his cousin Zara Tindall when discussing such matters with the Queen, and deciding which titles his child should use. Zara, who was born Miss Zara Phillips, has spoken of how not having a title was a blessing.  Ive been very lucky. My parents didnt give us titles, so weve been able to have a slightly more normal upbringing. As soon as youve got a title, its very dficult to shed it, she said. Harry too has told of the pressures of being a prince and has always stressed the importance of being seen as normal. He confessed in  that he once wanted out of the Royal Family. Harry said the time he spent in the Army - when he was just Harry - was the best escape Ive ever had and he once considered giving up his title.  I felt I wanted out but then decided to stay in and work out a role for myself, he said. The Earl and Countess of Wessexs children Lady Louise Mountbatten-Windsor and Viscount Severn are actually entitled to be a princess and prince as children of the son of the sovereign. But the couple decided, with the Queens agreement, that their children would use the courtesy titles as sons or daughters of an earl rather than the style prince or princess. An example of a royal duke handing down a courtesy title to his son is the Queens cousin the Duke of Gloucester when his son Alexander was born in .  Alex is known by the dukes subsidiary title Earl of Ulster, while the dukes daughters, before their marriages, were Lady Davina Windsor, and Lady Rose Windsor. Earl of Ulsters own son Xan - the dukes grandchild - is Lord Culleden - taken from the dukes third title Baron Culleden. If Harry had a son who had a son - Harrys grandchild - he would be Lord Kilkeel, taken from Harrys third title Baron Kilkeel.

title: historic drakes island goes market
story: NewsHistoric Drakes island goes on the market for £million - and could be developed into luxury retreatNamed after Sir Francis Drake, Drakes Island boasts six acres of land that is drenched in history from the Napoleonic eraShareCommentsByWilliam TelfordHana Carter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDrakes island has been put up for sale "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn historic island off the Devon coast is up for sale for poundmillion - and could be transformed into a Caribbean-style luxury retreat. Just off the coast of Plymouth and stretching out six acres, Drakes Island is dotted with buildings from the Napoleonic era. The island has a rich history including time spent as a prison during the reign of Charles II and was neamed after SI Francis Drake who set sail to circumnavigate the world in . Now on the market it also comes with planning permission for a spa and hotel.Aidan McCauley, son of the islands owner Dan McCauley, told BBC : My dad has long held a vision to see the island brought back into use.We are passionate about seeing his vision turned into a reality and are exploring all options to make this happen.  Mr McCauley had bought the land in the s and in  Plymouth City Council granted planning permission for the development of a luxury spa and hotel. The island was named after Sir Francis Drake, who had planned to sail from there in  to discover the world. Estate agents JLL are seeking initial expressions of interest with a guide price of poundmillion.The company told PlymouthLive : “Best and final offers are invited by a date to be announced. The owners are not obliged to accept any offer made.”But it stressed “detailed consideration is given to all the offers received”. In November  plans for a poundmillion-plus hotel and spa complex on the island were revealed. Engineering firm Rotolok Group, the island’s owner, wanted to create a resort and opening the island to the public. With planning consent secured in April , details were released showing how the Grade II-listed Island House, Barracks Block and Ablutions building could be linked to form a hotel containing  double- and twin-bedrooms. A new “lightweight contemporary” structure would be built to house a ground-floor bar, with restaurant and reception above. Another new building would contain a spa.  The Casemates battery was planned to be transformed into  “luxury” bedroom suites with sea views. The building could also accommodate rooms explaining the history of Drake’s Island. The plan also included landscaping, refurbishment of the jetty and infrastructure works. Bob King, project co-ordinator for the Drake’s Island development, said work has started on what will be a complex project. The initial focus will be to make the jetty safe for contractors and consultants to land, and then to bring utilities to the island.

story: NewsWhen is Meghan Markles baby due  Prince Harrys first child expected in SpringWhen is Spring  Well, the answer to that is not as simple as you may thinkShareByGavin AllenAssociate Editor:,  OCT NewsKensington Palaces official announcement says the couples baby is due in Spring "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe happy news that The Duchess of Sussex is expecting her first baby in the Spring of  has been revealed today. But for all the royal baby armchair detectives out there who want to know when the specic dates of Spring fall - to work out when to plan the street party - the answer is not as clear cut as you might think. There are actually two dferent dates for when Spring begins - Meteorological or Astronomical - so it depends on which system you use. To complicate it further, the seasons are not always the sameso the start and end dates can fall on a dferent times each year. The Meteorological seasons were created after the Astronomical seasons to try to help define the dates with greater accuracy. Astronomical seasons come roughly three weeks later than Meteorological Seasons, according to the Met Office. Meteorological spring  This looks at the seasons by weather are based on temperature cycles as well as the calendar This year it fell on March  and ended on May , and it  fall on the same dates. Astronomical spring  In  it begins on Wednesday, March  and ends on Friday, June . This is a more scientic measure and comes into effect when there is a . degree tilt of Earths rotational axis in relation to its orbit around the sun. Solstice and Equinox  The earths orbit in relation to the sun also defines equinoxes and solstices, which mark the transition from season to season. There are two equinoxes per year, Spring and Autumn. The dates are iable.The next Spring equinox will be Wednesday,  March,  The next Autumn equinox will be on September , There are two solstices, Summer and Winter.The next summer solstice will be June ,  The next winter solstice will be December , The four seasons
